reviewText: Is It Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon?

reviewText:
On October 31, 2013, a dungeon-crawling game known as Demon Master Chris was released. On May 31, 2016, its spiritual successor, Sakura Dungeon, was initially released on Nutaku, the version of which I have played for many hours already. (It’s why I have next to no time played on the Steam version, which I have purchased purely to leave this review. Yes, I care that much.) Now that it’s out on Steam, I can leave a more visible review of it here.

I want to love Sakura Dungeon. I really, really, do. I have played and replayed Demon Master Chris for some triple-digit hours. I’ve sunk more than twenty hours into Sakura Dungeon already, on the highest difficulty no less. Unfortunately, I’m finding that the more I play Sakura Dungeon, the more it makes me want to put it down and instead boot up Demon Master Chris once again.

Where Sakura Dungeon Succeeds
Firstly, let’s not sell Sakura Dungeon short where it inarguably surpasses Demon Master Chris. The artist has noticeably improved in the three years between the games, and the music and SFX are of much higher quality. Frankly, I think the plot might even be a little better; I enjoy the personalities of the main protagonists more. If you simply want to ogle cute and busty anime chicks in compromising situations, then stop reading here and buy Sakura Dungeon. It will be a purchase well worth your money.

My problem is that at heart, I’m a tryhard and a grognard who likes to delve deep into the inner mechanics of games. Just what is the game engine like underneath Sakura Dungeon’s new, sleek, and shiny chassis? What got tweaked from DMC that had me finding myself wanting to play the older version instead? In order to make a fair comparison and highlight the minor but important differences, I’ll have to explain DMC’s original system in more depth. Here comes a massive wall of text.

Demon Master Chris’s Combat System
Too long for Steam. Read the wall here: http://pastebin.com/1uCLbU4Q

Sparknotes:

VP is health, AP is stamina; You only ever need 1 VP but your current AP represents your ability to dodge; keeping AP high is important to survival
Guard command lets you use AP to temporarily boost dodge in the short term, while Recover command lets you recover AP for later usage but temporarily decreases dodge; Guard/Recover duality means that defensive play has meaningful choice and means that paying attention to the enemy is important
Read your opponent, learn their general rhythm, then try to anticipate it to dodge their attacks and exploit their attempt to Recover
Attacks against low AP characters turn into Critical Hits, which also cause clothing damage; naked characters lose all VP regen and thus can be taken down with ease
Random encounters remain legitimate threats unless you are absolutely positively ridiculously overleveled
Bosses absolutely must be outwitted and stripped in order to reasonably defeat them
Sakura Dungeon’s Simplications, Changes to DMC’s System
Still too long for Steam. Read the longform here: http://pastebin.com/nyTx2yZs

Moar sparknotes:

Sakura Dungeon replaces Guard/Recover duality with a single, one-dimensional command that simply restores AP with no downside or other effect, thus removing the rock-paper-scissors triangle of Recover->Guard->Attack->Recover for an overly simple continuum of be defensive<-->attack more"
Dodge gain from high AP reduced
date: attacks are more accurate in general: now the majority of all attacks hit their targets without having to consider the target's own AP
recommended: meaning random encounters become boring and routine extremely quickly\nCritical Hits now far less dependent on AP state of target; attacks on low AP targets not guaranteed to crit
hoursPlayed: while high AP targets can sometimes still be crit anyways\nLess predictable nature of Critical Hits mainly serves to surprise and annoy the player
voteText: instead of directly rewarding you for playing well or punishing you for making mistakes\nStripping to eliminate regen mechanic simplified; changes rhythm of boss fights entirely
helpfulPercent: turns bosses into statchecks rather than actual thinking challenges; devs outright encourage the player to simply grind to prepare for bosses
votesHelpful: rather than rethink their strategy or try different approaches\nCP/Flow system that Sakura Dungeon introduced feels snowbally without adding very much interaction with the opponent; since bosses have been turned into statchecks

votesFunny: boring "strategy" of "grind until you can beat the boss lol"\nWhere DMC plays like a fighting game with thinking forward and counterplay

reviewText: I'm a fan of similar games such as Legends of Grimrock, Elminage Gothic, and Wizardy 8, but I simply could not enjoy this game. The setting was a typical JRPG setting, the characters were interesting enough, and the music was fantastic. However my biggest complaint is the lack of depth and character building. My favorite part of dungeon crawlers is the character building, building an effective party, and equiping them properly. Sakura Dungeon lacks all of this type of depth I have come to expect from dungeon crawlers. All you have is 6 abilities per character (Half of which are chosen by default), and some basic stats. No gear, and hardly any stat or ability progression. I wanted to like Sakura Dungeon, but I simply couldn't, it lacked some basic elements which make the Dungeon Crawler genre so much fun.

reviewText: I cannot believe they are trying to sell this for $20 dollars. There was no work put into this game. There are no animations, there are no voices. The combat is so incredibly dull. All you do is click on a strong attack, weak attack or guard. It is so painfully dull. It is so dull that they even put a system where you can fastforward through the battles! What else is there besides fastforwardable battles? Oh yeah, fastforwardable text! The artwork is decent enough. It's not that high quality though. I didn't personally enjoy it. $20.00? I mean, hey. If people will buy it and like it. I guess that's demand and supply but I found this title incredibly lackluster. This title is worth 5$ to maybe $10 at the very most. If a title is going to be sold for $20 dollars there needs to be more work put into it. I mean I could have sat down and created a game via RPGMaker that had 10 times more content than this game in a very short period of time by myself.

reviewText:
So at the time of this writing I am about 11.5 hours into the game, and so far I can say in pleasantly surprised.
The plot is sweet and simple and they stick to it the whole time, which I can appreciate. Sure, I've had to grind up a level or two on hard, but that is expected with a RPG.

The cast of characters each have their own personality and don't fit into that cookie cutter mold of a typical lemming. I can say that you will defidently be keeping certain characters and shuffling though others as they get outdated on later floors. I've encountered about maybe 15~ monster girls but I know that's barely scratching the surface. Also love that they have unique dialogue. (Great sprites aswell)

However there is one big thing I hate about this game, the save system. I really don't like how this game doesn't auto save but that's just me. I've only died twice and I've had to makeup about an hour of gameplay by forgetting to save. But this is mostly because I'm stupid.

Besides that, all in all I reccomend you pick up this game as it isn't your typical VN and there are a lot of fun elements.
Buy. This. Game.

reviewText:
Despite the hate the Sakura series gets, this game actually has some decent production value. Especially if you update it with the H patch, or purchase an uncensored version from Denpasoft or Nutaku.

The formula of the game is nearly identical to Demon Master Chris, capture girls and they join your party, get lots of H scenes along the way. There's leveling up, stats, different attacks, resistances, etc.

It's a competent enough erotic dungeon crawler.

reviewText:
Can get a little grindy here and there, but overall, I'm impressed.  It feels like they actually put substantial work into this game.  One of the best parts is that your random party members will comment on different events, granting the illusion that they are actually living party members instead of just some pretty sprites.  Art is awesome, the music can get downright gorgeous, and the combat is fast-paced and fun; though those wishing for some more strategy will be dissapointed.

Either way, definitely a good grab, though a little expensive.  For 10-15, I would suggest it 100%.  For 20?  Mmmm... depends.  For me, definitely worth it.  Anime waifus galore are worth all the moneys :3

I really hope that they make another game, albeit with more features and such, in the future.  I would definitely be willing to buy more from this series... and please, no more hack Sakura VNs... do more Dungeon!  And more cat girls! :3

P.S. My congrats to the writer of the two main characters, fyi.  Yomi is especially likeable and fun.  Very good job.

reviewText:
Product received for free

First and foremost, I unexpectedly (but gratefully) received an early access key from Winged Cloud for this game. Honestly, I wasn't expecting much beyond the standard fare of what we've all come to know of the Sakura series: mammories. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the game has a level of depth that now places the Sakura series in the company of something greater than just VN eye candy. In my humble opinion, they really needed something to freshen up what seemed to be a rinse-and-repeat model, and I think they've done an excellent job achieving that here.

Right from the start, the artwork is beautiful (as it is through the majority of the Sakura series), but there's something significantly wonderful in this game: excellent, memorable music! After digging into it, I found that Zack Parrish is the one who composed the music (he also composed the music for Sakura Fantasy, which was also quite excellent).

Once hopping into the game, it begins with a setup for events to come. Personally, I get bored with VNs pretty quickly, so I initially wondered how long I was going to have to click-click-click-click-click to get to something, uhhhh, enticing? Luckily, it didn't take long. Once stepping into the inn after a few minutes, there she was: my new waifu, Isabella.

Anyway, fast forward to entering the dungeon, where you will roam and randomly encounter monsters" (see: boobs). You get their HP down low enough and bye-bye clothes (not uncensored
recommended: but sufficient enough for a potential party in your pantaloons). You can capture them and add them to your party eventually
hoursPlayed: but this is a good time to mention the depth of the game's RPG elements: grinding ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) to level up
voteText: XP

column24: thanks to its interactive RPG mechanics that bridge the gap between clickity-click-click-click-click VN and something akin to a an 8-bit-era dungeon crawler.\n\nI've only made it to the level-2 dungeon at the moment
column25: so I think it's too soon for a pros/cons (primarily because I don't have any cons right now). All I can say is if you've indulged in the previous Sakura VNs and enjoyed them
column26: I think you'll be impressed with what Winged Cloud has managed to achieve here--provided you're into RPGs. If you're as impatient as I can be with VNs

reviewText: Look, it's a hentai dungeon crawler, either you like it or don't it's up to you to decide if you want to spend your money on it. You do more in this game than just constantly click on a shiny girl until she disappears only to have another one in an interminable loop. Not progressed far enough to make an accurate statement but if you don't expect a serious challenge and enjoy rpg/dungeoncrawler games, should certainly have some fun with it. Lovely soundtrack as well. Just keep in mind it's still very much a visual novel game (skipable dialog). Uncensored patch is available, can find it on the forums here - Thanks for the link 'Maou'!

reviewText: It's a step up from the other games. Good enough production values for the pricepoint (expecially if you got it on sale at some point), repeatative but compotent combat, and a lot of (unvoiced) dialouge. I dont really like ecchi games that much, but I like yuri games enough to offset that.\n\nI haven't gotten too too far, but I am disappointed in the fact that every character looks the same apart from hairstyle and clothing. Same body types and mostly pale complexions. There is also a lack of more modest clothing styles, so the ripped clothing" feature of the game doesn't really make a difference

reviewText:
Product received for free

Howdy Doody Everyboody!

You can hear the enjoyment from me in my playthrough ^_^: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=693333744

I have been waiting for this game since it was announced and so far it has exceeded my expectations. At first I thought this game was going to be another visual novel but it's actually a mix between rpg/dungeon crawler and visual novel!

I like the combat system and that if your frontline character get knocked out, someone from the backline steps in so you don't need to use up a turn to get some one out there! You also get to capture cute monster girls and have them in your team! Yay!

Would I recommend this game? Yes I would because it is different and not just a visual novel but with an rpg element to it!
